questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Huntington's chorea?

choices.text: It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
There is loss of function type of mutation
There are abnormal repeats of CUG
Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 6

questions.solution:
Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.

It is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder. It is caused by CAG trinucleotide repeats (>40). It occurs due to a gain-of-function (expansion) mutation in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4p. 

The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (2-3 decades) if inherited from the father. 

Cognitive impairment is an early feature. Pathologically, atrophy of caudate and putamen with ex vacuo ventriculomegaly is seen. Decreased acetylcholine leads to dementia and decreased GABA and increased dopamine lead to chorea.

Treatment consists of haloperidol and tetrabenazine.

Trinucleotide repeat disorders:

Disease Repeats Clinical features
Fragile X- syndrome   CGG Mental retardation, large ears, and jaws, macroorchidism in males

Myotonic Dystrophy

(chromosome 19)

   CTG Muscle loss, cardiac arrhythmia,
cataracts, frontal balding
Huntington’s disease   CAG Affective disorder
Spinocerebellar ataxia type 1   CAG Progressive ataxia, dysarthria,
dysmetria.
Friedreich's ataxia   GAA Progressive ataxia,
dysarthria, hypertrophic
cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the pathology of achalasia cardia?

choices.text: Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus
Decreased tone of the  lower esophageal sphincter

questions.solution:
Achalasia cardia is characterized by decreased release of NO(nitric oxide) and VIP(vasoactive intestinal polypeptide) in the distal part of esophagus.

Normally, NO and VIP are secreted by the inhibitory neurons of the Auerbach's plexus in the distal esophagus. This leads to relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). In achalasia cardia, these inhibitory neurons degenerate leading to decreased release of NO and VIP. This causes increased LES tone.

The triad of achalasia cardia is as follows:

  1. Incomplete relaxation of LES
  2. Increased tone of LES
  3. Absent peristalsis (aperistalisis)

questions.text: A patient presents with midline swelling in the neck. Biopsy revealing Orphan Annie eye nuclei is shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of empty appearing nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei as seen in the above image is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma include:

  • Branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk
  • Covering epithelium is simple or stratified cuboidal
  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei - 
    • Empty-appearing nuclei due to dispersed chromatin
    • They are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture
  • Psammoma bodies - concentric calcified structures
  • Foci of lymphatic invasion 

 The image below shows papillary thyroid carcinoma with characteristic Orphan Annie eye nuclei:

Note: Orphan Annie refers to a comic book character with empty appearing eyes.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient came with complaints of hematuria to the clinic. On examination, he was normotensive and had pedal edema. Investigations revealed the patient had no glycosuria and had a creatinine of 9. His renal biopsy is shown below. Which of the following investigations should be done to identify the disease?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical history and microscopy showing crescents, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is suspected. Among the given options, anti- GBM antibody testing should be done, since it is a part of the work-up of RPGN.

Type 1 RPGN includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. In this condition, antibodies are produced against the non-collagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM.

Microscopy findings of Goodpasture's disease are:

  • Immunofluorescence - linear deposits of Ig and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron microscopy - wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focal disruptions without any immune complex deposition.

A variant of Goodpasture's disease with pulmonary involvement is known as Goodpasture's syndrome.

Option A: ANA testing is done if SLE is suspected. Electron microscopy will show immune complex deposits.

Option C: HIV RNA testing is done in immunodeficiency syndrome associated with weight loss. Electron microscopy will show diffuse podocyte injury with complete foot process effacement. Tubuloreticular inclusions will be seen in endothelial cells.

Option D: Urine electrophoresis is done if nephrotic syndrome is suspected.

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Disease

 Light microscopy Fluorescence microscopy

Electron microscopy

Postinfectious glomerulo-nephritis

Diffuse endocapillary proliferation; leukocytic infiltration

Granular IgA in some cases

Alport syndrome

Nephrotic syndrome:

Membranous  nephropathy

Diffuse capillary wall thickening

Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

 

Subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes), effacement of podocyte 

Minimal change disease

Normal; lipid in tubules

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte

No deposits.

Nephrito-nephrotic syndrome:

(MPGN) type I

Subendothelial deposits

Dense-deposit disease (MPGN type II)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with a retroperitoneal mass. Biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. Molecular analysis revealed t(12;16).  What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myxoid liposarcoma. 

The image shows abundant ground substance, with branching capillaries and a few immature adipocytes. 

Liposarcoma is the most common sarcoma in adults and is usually seen in the 5th to 6th decade of life. They commonly occur in the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and in the retroperitoneum.

Histologically the liposarcomas are divided into three subtypes:

  • Well-differentiated liposarcoma: It consists of mature adipocytes and scattered spindle cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. It is associated with amplification of 12q13-q15.
  • Myxoid liposarcoma: It contains abundant basophilic extracellular matrix with branching capillaries. Few immature adipocytes are found scattered within the matrix. It is associated with t(12;16).
  • Pleomorphic liposarcoma: It consists of sheets of anaplastic cells with bizarre nuclei and few immature adipocytes.

Among the three subtypes, the pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while the well-differentiated is least malignant. Myxoid liposarcoma has intermediate malignancy behaviour.

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.

Infective endocarditis is characterized by the presence of large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves. Aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, however, in some cases, the right heart valves may be involved.

Vegetations may be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves. Embolization often occurs and may lead to septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgement due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli.

Related Pearl: Vegetations in Various Types of Endocarditis

heart disease

vein thrombosis,

destructive

both sides of the valve leaflets.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with a history of fatigue and tiredness. On investigation, he was found to have Hb = 9 gm% and MCV =101 FL. Peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic RBC and hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
The given findings are suggestive of macrocytic anaemia, which can be seen in chronic alcoholics.

Anemic patients with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia.

Chronic alcoholics also have deficiency of folic acid due to:

  • Trapping of folate within the liver
  • Excessive urinary loss
  • Disordered folate metabolism
  • Inadequate dietary intake is frequently encountered in chronic alcoholics

Related Pearl: Morphological Classification of Anemias

 

Microcytic Hypochromic

(MCV <80 fl)

Normocytic Normochromic    

(MCV 80 - 100 fl)

Macrocytic Normochromic

(MCV >100 fl)

Iron deficiency anemia

Sideroblastic anemia

Thalassemia

Lead toxicity

Acute blood loss

Anemia of chronic disease

Anemia of renal disease

Hemolysis*

Bone marrow suppression

  • Aplastic anemia
  • Pure red cell aplasia

 

  

Megaloblastic:

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Folate deficiency

Thiamine deficiency

Drugs - Methotrexate, Zidovudine, hydroxyurea

Orotic aciduria

 

Non-megaloblastic:

Alcohol use

Liver disease

Hypothyroidism

Hemolysis*

 

*Hemolysis can be associated with macrocytosis because of compensatory reticulocytosis. However, MCV can be normal depending on the degree of hemolysis.

Note: In Orotic Aciduria, peripheral blood smear shows Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.

Juvenile polyps are malformations of epithelium and lamina propria commonly located in the rectum. It is seen in children <5 years of age. The typical presentation is painless rectal bleeding. Sometimes there may be a proliferating rectal mass.

The disease may be sporadic or syndromic. 

  • Sporadic juvenile polyp occurs as a single mass and is called retention polyp.
  • Juvenile polyposis syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps, which may be premalignant.

Morphologically, both of these types are indistinguishable.

  • Gross appearance: They appear as pedunculated, smooth reddish lesions, and with cystic spaces.
  • Microscopic appearance: The cysts appear as dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris.

Note: Complex glandular architecture and the presence of smooth muscle cutting through the lamina propria are seen in Peutz-Jeghers polyps.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the histopathological findings are suggestive of celiac disease.

Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy where HLA DQ2 and DQ8 are expressed. In the small intestine, peptides of gluten are presented to helper T cells which mediate mucosal inflammation. Antiendomysial and anti-tTG antibodies are found in serological studies.

Clinically, malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss is seen along with chronic refractory anemia. Dermatitis herpetiformis is seen in 10% of patients with celiac disease. Microscopic findings show villi atrophy, villi flattening, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes (IEL).

Option A: Environmental enteropathy / tropical sprue is seen in tropical areas with poor sanitation. It is believed to be caused by one or more infectious agents that respond to antibiotics. Mucosa shows variable villous atrophy.

Option C: Whipple's disease is a multisystemic disease caused by T.whipplei. Small intestinal biopsy shows PAS-positive macrophages.

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

The following are the general tests for malabsorption:

Disorder Investigation
Fat malabsorption

Quantitative: 24h fecal fat >7g

Qualitative: Sudan III staining

C14 Triolein breath test

Fecal steatocrit
Carbohydrate malabsorption

D-xylose test

Lactose hydrogen breath test
Protein malabsorption C13 egg-white breath test

The following are the specific tests for malabsorption:

Disorder Investigation
Celiac disease

Anti-tissue transglutaminase (anti-tTG)

Anti-endomysial antibodies

Mucosal biopsy showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, lamina propria infiltrates, and normal mucosal thickness.
Whipple's disease Mucosal biopsy showing PAS +ve macrophages in lamina propria
Pancreatic insufficiency

Fecal elastase

Fecal chymotrypsin
Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)

Due to Enterobacter or Pseudomonas - jejunal aspirate >103 CFU

Due to other organisms - jejunal aspirate >105 CFU

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since past 5 days.  There is desquamative skin rash, oedema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.

Clinical features include:

  • Fever
  • Conjunctival and oral erythema
  • Blistering, edema of hands and feet
  • Erythema of palms and soles
  • Desquamative rash
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy

The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction. Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis.

It is also seen in other conditions such as membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Since the podocytes are affected in these diseases, they are also known as podocytopathies.

The effacement of foot process can only be observed on electron microscopy.

questions.text: Thrombosis is initiated by:
questions.solution:
Thrombosis is initiated by endothelial injury.

Thrombosis is is the formation of a blood clot inside a blood vessel, obstructing the flow of blood through the circulatory system. 

Three primary abnormalities, often referred to as Virchow triad, are known to induce thrombosis. They include:

  • Endothelial injury - most important factor
  • Stasis or turbulent blood flow
  • Hypercoagulability of the blood

Related Pearl: Arterial and Venous Thrombi

Feature Arterial thrombus Venous thrombus
Pathogenesis Endothelial injury or site of turbulence Stasis of blood
Blood flow Associated with active blood flow Associated with sluggish blood flow
Sites Coronary, cerebral and femoral arteries Superficial and deep leg veins, ovarian periuterine veins
Propagation Grows in a retrograde manner from point of attachment Grows in an antegrade manner from point of attachment
Line of Zahn Present Present
Microscopic

Friable meshwork of platelets, fibrin, red cells, and degenerating leukocytes (White thrombi).

 Red cells mixed with relatively less platelets, so also called as red thrombi
Occlusion Incomplete lumen occlusion Complete vessel occlusion
Complications Ischemia and infarction of organs Embolism, edema and ulceration

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Hurthle ​cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with the presence of Hurthle cells is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

It is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in women between 45 to 65 years of age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase.

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures.

Microscopic features include:

  • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed germinal centers
  • Atrophied thyroid follicles 
  • The epithelial cells lining the follicles contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm
    • This is called oncocytic metaplasia
    • These cells are called Hurthle cells

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen this patient?
questions.solution:
The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Anemic patient with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the main causes of megaloblastic anemia.

Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies which impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF). This is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:

  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.

These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells.

Related Pearl: Difference between B12 and Folic acid Deficiency

Laboratory Tests

Pernicious Anemia (B12 Deficiency)

Folic Acid Deficiency

Serum B12 level

Decreased

Normal

Serum folic acid level

Normal

Decreased

Serum LDH level

Increased

Normal

Achlorhydria

Present

Absent

Schilling Test

Positive

Negative

Methyl malonyl CoA in urine

Present

Absent

Neurological signs

Present

Absent

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast.

Colloid carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intracellular and extracellular mucin deposition.

On histopathological examination, extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei, arranged in clusters, floating in lakes or pools of mucin. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the periphery to form a signet ring appearance.

Option B: Microscopic image of papillary carcinoma of the breast showing true papillae with a leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue lined by the tumor cells is shown below.

Option C: Microscopic image of medullary carcinoma of the breast consisting of sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures (anaplastic cells), lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate is shown below.

Option D: Microscopic image of lobular carcinoma of the breast shows infiltrating small monomorphic discohesive tumor cells arranged in an Indian-file or single-file pattern is shown below.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease?

choices.text: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.solution:
Hirschsprung disease occurs due to the failure of migration of the neural crest cells to the bowel wall.

During normal embryogenesis, the neural crest cells migrate from the caecum to the rectum. The enteric neuronal plexuses develop from these migrated neural crest cells.

In Hirschsprung disease, there is an arrest in the migration of these cells, which leads to the development of a distal intestinal segment that is devoid of Meissner (submucosal) and the Auerbach (myenteric) plexus. Hence this segment is referred to as the aganglionic segment.

As a result, there is a lack of coordination in the peristaltic contractions and functional obstruction, which further leads to the dilation of the intestine proximal to the affected segment, leading to congenital megacolon. Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating the absence of ganglion cells in biopsy sections.

Some conditions may cause acquired megacolon. These include:

  • Chagas disease, due to the loss of ganglion cells
  • Visceral myopathy
  • Obstruction by neoplasm or inflammatory stricture
  • Toxic megacolon complicating ulcerative colitis
  • Functional psychosomatic disorders

questions.text: Premature aging in Werner syndrome is due to:

choices.text: Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity

questions.solution:
Premature aging in Werner syndrome is due to a defect in DNA helicase.

DNA helicase is involved in DNA replication and repair and other functions requiring DNA unwinding. A defect in this enzyme causes rapid accumulation of damaged chromosomes that may mimic the injury that normally accumulates during cellular aging.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

Diseases

Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ)

Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)

Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease(RS-SCID)

Defective Homologous Repair (HR)

AT-like disorder (ATLD)

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

Breast cancer suspectibility 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2)

Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)

Cockayne syndrome (CS)

Trichothiodystrophy (TTD)

Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER)

MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP)

Defective DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR)

Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

questions.text: A 24-year-old presented with swelling in the wrist joint. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei and Verocay bodies. Which of the following is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
The histopathological examination is suggestive of schwannoma. Features showing spindle cells with palisading nuclei and Verocay bodies are characteristic of schwannoma.

Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that abut the associated nerve without invading it. They are commonly associated with inactivating mutations in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22q12.

Microscopically, it consists of dense areas called Antoni A, and loose areas called Antoni B.

  • The Antoni A areas contain spindle cells that are arranged into intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is seen, with nuclear-free zones between them, forming structures called Verocay bodies.
  • The Antoni B areas contain spindle-shaped cells that are loosely arranged separated by prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

The image below shows cellular Antoni A and paucicellullar Antoni B areas in schwannoma.

The image below shows verocay bodies in the Antoni-A area of vestibular schwannoma.

questions.text: B-cells are induced to produce IgE by which of the following:
questions.solution:
IL-4 stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE secreting plasma cells.

Related Pearl: T Helper cells- Types and functions

Cell Type

T helper cell 1

T helper 2

T helper 17

Major cytokines produced

IFN-γ

IL-4, IL-5, IL-13

IL-17, IL-22

Cytokines that induce this subset

IFN-γ, IL-12

IL-4

TGF-β, IL-6, IL-1, IL-23

Immunological reactions triggered

Macrophage activation, stimulation of IgG antibody production

Stimulation of IgE production, activation of mast cells and eosinophils

Recruitment of neutrophils, monocytes

Host defense against

Intracellular microbes

Helminthic parasites

Extracellular bacteria, fungi

Role in disease

Autoimmune and other chronic inflammatory diseases (such as IBD, psoriasis, granulomatous inflammation)

Allergies

Autoimmune and other chronic inflammatory diseases (such as IBD, psoriasis, MS)

questions.text: The lining epithelium of the respiratory tract of a middle-aged man who is a chronic smoker shows a change from columnar to stratified squamous epithelium, as depicted in the image below. The change is called:
questions.solution:
The change described in the question is called metaplasia. It is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

The table below shows various types of metaplasia:

Tissue Metaplasia Cause
Airways Squamous metaplasia: Normal pseudostratified epithelium is replaced by the squamous epithelium. 

Chronic smoking,

Deficiency of retinoic acid
Urinary bladder Squamous metaplasia: Normal transitional epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium. Bladder stones 
Esophagus Columnar metaplasia: Normal squamous epithelium is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barret's esophagus) Chronic GERD 
Cervix Squamous metaplasia: Normal glandular epithelium may be replaced by the squamous epithelium. Low pH of the cervix
Muscle Connective tissue metaplasia: Formation of bone in the muscle tissue; (myositis ossificans). After intramuscular hemorrhage

GERD: Gastroesophageal reflux disease

questions.text: Graft from identical twin is called:
questions.solution:
A graft from an identical twin is called an isograft.

Isograft is defined as an organ or tissue that is taken from a donor and is transplanted to a recipient who has the same genetic constitution as the donor. For example, graft between identical twins.

Related Pearl: Types of transplants

Type  Definition
Orthotopic

Organ implanted in the same anatomic location in the recipient as it was in the donor. Diseased organ is removed. Eg: heart, lung, liver, intestine
Heterotopic

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location. Diseased organ is left in place. Eg: Kidney, pancreas
Auxiliary transplantation Partial tissue from the donor is used which acts as temporary support for the recipient's injured organ, which remains in place. Eg: left lobe of liver
Autotransplant  Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same person. 
Allotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same species. 
Xenotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs in a different species.
Isograft Transfer of organ or tissue within genetically identical individuals. Eg: Identical twins

questions.text: Histology of reperfused myocardium:
questions.solution:
Reperfused myocardium shows eosinophilic contraction bands on light microscopy. They occur in irreversibly injured myocytes with damaged membranes, when blood supply is restored 12-24 hours after MI.

During ischemia, the intracellular levels of calcium are increased due to impaired calcium cycling and sarcolemmal damage. This leads to augmented and uncontrolled contraction of myofibrils after reperfusion. 

On microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that are intensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closely packed sarcomeres.

Reperfused infarcts are usually hemorrhagic because the vasculature is injured during ischemia. This leads to bleeding after the flow is restored.

Related Pearl: The Temporal Evolution of the Morphologic Changes in Acute MI

Time

Gross Features

Microscopy features

Reversible Injury

0-1/2 hr

None

EM: Relaxation of myofibrils; glycogen loss; mitochondrial swelling

LM: None

Irreversible Injury 

1/2-4 hr

None

EM: Sarcolemmal disruption; mitochondrial amorphous densities

LM: Usually none; variable waviness of fibers at border

4-12 hr

Dark mottling (occasional)

LM: Early coagulation necrosis, edema, hemorrhage

12-24 hr

Dark mottling

LM: Ongoing coagulation necrosis, pyknosis of nuclei, myocyte hypereosinophilia, marginal contraction band necrosis, early neutrophilic infiltrate

1-3 days

Mottling with yellow-tan infarct center

LM: Coagulation necrosis, with loss of nuclei and striations, brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils

3-7 days

Hyperemic border, central yellow-tan softening

LM: Begining disintegration of dead myofibres, with dying neutrophils, early phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at the infarct border

7-10 days

Maximally yellow-tan and soft with depressed red-tan margins

LM: Well-developed phagocytosis of dead cells; granulation tissue at margins

10-14 days

Red-grey depressed infarct borders

LM: Well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and collagen deposition

2-8 wk

Grey-white scar, progressive from the  border towards the core of the infarct

LM: increased collagen deposition, with decreased cellularity

>2 mo

Scarring complete

LM: Dense collagenous scar

EM: Electron microscopy

LM: Light microscopy

questions.text: All-trans retinoic acid is used in the treatment of tumor that is associated with which of the following genetic aberrations?
questions.solution:
All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML), which is associated with PML-RARA fusion gene.

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) is associated with a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17 producing a PML-RARA fusion gene. This fusion gene encodes for a chimeric protein, which consists of a part of the PML protein and a part of the retinoic acid receptor-α (RARα).

The normal RARα binds to the DNA and activates the transcription in the presence of retinoids. However, the chimeric protein produced by PML-RARA has reduced affinity for retinoids. This causes inhibition of transcription, thereby preventing gene expression for cellular differentiation. This leads to the accumulation of myeloid progenitor cells.

The condition is treated with all-trans retinoic acid. It binds to the PML-RARA chimeric protein. This causes conformational change such that the protein regains its normal function and activates DNA transcription.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with 15 days of cough. On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy was noted and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological picture showing the caseating granuloma, eosinophilic necrotic debris known as caseation, bordered by collections of epithelioid cells, Langhan giant cells (horse shoe shape) and lymphocytes and clinical history is suggestive of tuberculosis.

Clinically, tuberculosis presents with chronic cough, fever, weight loss, swollen lymph nodes.

Other options:

Option B- Leprosy presents with skin lesions and nerve involvement with loss of sensation.

Option C- Sarcoidosis shows giant cells with cytoplasmic inclusions, non-caseating granuloma with fibroblastic proliferation at the periphery.

Option D- Syphilis shows thickened capsule/ hyperplasia of capsule accompanied by fibrosis, perivascular inflammation, and infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells.

The below image shows histopathological findings seen in tuberculosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, and wheezing died of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was not a smoker or an alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown?
questions.solution:
The above gross specimen shows emphysematous damage involving enlargement of the entire acinus suggestive of panacinar emphysema. It is caused due to alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency.

In panacinar (panlobular) emphysema, the acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli. It occurs commonly in the lower zones and in the anterior margins of the lung and is most severe at the bases.

The image below shows panacinar emphysema.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

Type Area involved Other features

Centriacinar (most common)
  • Central part of acinus (respiratory bronchiole)
  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar
  • Entire acinus (respiratory bronchiole + alveoli)
  • Lower lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in young non-smokers
  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal
  • Distal part of acinus (alveoli)
  • Subpleural region
  • Commonly seen in young adults 
  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular
  • Focal and irregular involvement of acinus
  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text: A 6-foot-5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition.
questions.solution:
The patient's height and the presence of early diastolic murmur in the given clinical scenario are suggestive of Marfan syndrome. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant disorder. The family pedigree confirms the mode of inheritance.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

Patients with Marfan syndrome have pleiotropic manifestations:

  • Skeletal systems - Tall and decreased upper to lower segment ratio with long arms, hands, and fingers
  • Deformities of the chest wall, vertebral column, and foot arches
  • Cardiovascular abnormalities - mitral valve prolapse leading to mitral regurgitation and dilatation of aortic root leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture.
  • Ocular - superio-temporal lens dislocation
